speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about when these symptoms started, was it sudden or did they develop over time?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, doc, it kinda came on out of nowhere. I was feeling pretty good one minute, and the next, I just started feeling really anxious and restless.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you describe the anxiety and restlessness you're experiencing? Is it more of a feeling of impending doom or a sense of intense worry about everyday things?

speaker: Patient
text: It's more like a feeling of intense worry, I guess. I just can't seem to shake off this feeling of being really on edge, like something's gonna go wrong at any moment.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily routine and activities? Have you noticed any triggers or situations that seem to make your anxiety worse?

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, doc, I've been pretty active, just been working out and hanging out with friends. I don't really notice any specific triggers, but I do get pretty anxious when I'm in crowded places or when I've got a lot on my plate. Like, yesterday I was at a party and it was really loud, and I just felt like I was gonna lose it, you know?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns? Are you having trouble sleeping or staying asleep, and if so, do you wake up feeling refreshed or still anxious?

speaker: Patient
text: Doc, to be honest, I've been having a hard time sleeping lately. I'll lie down, but I'll just end up lying there, wide awake, thinking about all the things that are stressing me out. And when I do manage to fall asleep, I wake up feeling pretty anxious, like my mind's still racing.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your appetite and energy levels? Have you noticed any changes in your usual eating habits or physical performance? And by the way, I'd like to take a look at your hands and feet to see if there are any notable changes in color or texture.

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, doc, I haven't really noticed a big change in my appetite, but I have been eating a bit more than usual, I guess, just because I'm trying to calm my nerves. As for energy levels, I feel pretty drained, to be honest, like I'm always running on empty.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your energy levels? Do you feel like you're able to get through your daily activities without needing to rest, or do you find yourself needing to take breaks more often than usual? Also, I'd like to examine your hands and feet more closely. Can you please show me your hands and feet, and are there any areas that are particularly sensitive or tender to the touch?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say I'm pretty exhausted all the time, doc. I need to take breaks just to recharge my batteries, you know? And yeah, my hands and feet are a bit...yellowish, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your liver function? Have you noticed any changes in how you feel after consuming certain foods or drinks? Also, can you point out exactly where on your hands and feet the yellowish coloring is most prominent?

speaker: Patient
text: Yeah, doc, I've noticed that after drinking, especially beer, I feel pretty crummy for a few hours afterwards. My stomach hurts, I feel nauseous, and I just feel really drained. And yeah, the yellowing of my skin and eyes is pretty noticeable, especially on my hands and feet. It's like my fingers and toes are really pale and yellow at the same time.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your liver more closely, so can you please remove your shoes and socks for me? I'd also like to request an imaging test to take a closer look at your liver, so REQUEST TEST: Ultrasound_of_Liver. Also, can you show me the exact areas on your hands and feet where the yellowing is most prominent?

text: Doc, I don't really have a family history of anything, but my mom's been dealing with some health issues lately. She's had some problems with her liver, but I don't think it's anything serious. She's just been getting a lot of tests done, you know?

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that your symptoms have been quite persistent. Can you tell me more about your emotional state? How are you coping with the anxiety and restlessness, and are there any things that seem to help or worsen it?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, doc, I've been trying to just power through, you know? I've been trying to stay busy and keep my mind off things, but it's hard when you're feeling this anxious and on edge all the time. Sometimes I just feel like I'm losing control, like I'm going to snap or something. It's really tough to deal with.

speaker: Doctor
text: I can see that you're struggling to cope with your symptoms, and that's understandable. Can you tell me more about what you think might be causing your anxiety and restlessness? Is there anything in particular that's on your mind, or any specific situations that seem to trigger it? And, I'd like to request some more information about your medication history. Have you taken any new medications recently, or changed your dosage of any existing medications?

speaker: Patient
text: Honestly, doc, I've been thinking a lot about it, and I'm not really sure. I mean, I've been using cocaine and ecstasy occasionally, and I know those can be pretty harsh on the body. But I don't think that's the only thing, because my mom's been dealing with similar issues, and I know she doesn't use those things. I'm just really worried that something's going on with my liver or something, and I don't know what to do about it.
